Towards a Generative Pictographic System

Cognitive Accessibility and Inclusive Communication

Herbert Spencer González
Postgraduate Research Symposium, 2025

Introduce the research focus and significance of cognitive accessibility.

Context and Motivation

  • Increasing complexity of public services and digital interfaces.
  • Accessibility as a fundamental right rather than an optional feature.
  • Pictograms as a bridge between linguistic intent and visual representation.
Emphasise the relevance of cognitive accessibility in contemporary service design.

Research Questions

  • How might a generative pictographic system support user self-determination?
  • Which design principles ensure both accessibility and adaptability?
  • How can a federated architecture facilitate collective evolution?

System Overview: PictoNet Architecture

Semantic Processing

Tokenisation using Natural Semantic Metalanguage (NSM).

Conceptual Blending

Integration of semantic primitives into composite concepts.

SVG Composition

Assembly of vector elements into coherent pictograms.

Methodology: Data Collection

  1. Contextual observation of interactions.
  2. Semi-structured interviews with AAC professionals.
  3. Design probes using pictogram sets.

Methodology: Analysis & Validation

  • Thematic analysis of qualitative data.
  • Evaluation against NSM-based criteria.
  • Community-driven validation via federated contributions.

Generative Pipeline

Module Function Key Parameter
Tokenisation NSM Mapping semantic_depth
Blending Concept Fusion max_combinations
Layout Spatial Arrangement aspect_ratio
Rendering SVG Assembly style_profile

Federated Architecture

Enables local adaptation while maintaining a shared core model.
